easy.notes: Categories are simple and concrete. Group 1 pairs common fruits with recognizable colors (red/green/yellow are common for these items in kids' contexts); Group 2 lists familiar playthings; Group 3 uses common pets and a frog; Group 4 lists basic shapes. Near-miss temptation avoided; no item overlaps between groups.

medium.notes: Category 1 hinges on the common prefix 'play-' forming a family of related words. Category 2 groups everyday household items. Category 3 contains snack/food items that share simple, familiar contexts. Category 4 lists weather descriptors. Near-miss: 'cookie' and 'crackers' could conceptually be snacks like 'yogurt', but each item clearly belongs to its own group. No homophones or hidden tricks; straightforward semantic links.

hard.notes: Category 1 uses common words with silent letters; category 2 presents obvious word-pairs but ensure items stay as separate entries rather than merged phrases. Category 3 lists common household items; Category 4 lists basic color words tied to emotions conceptually but keep distinct from the other groups. Near-miss temptation: 'green' and 'blue' could seem related to mood, but in this puzzle they are treated as color tokens; they do not cross into emotional meanings. All items are unambiguous and age-appropriate; no overlap between groups.
